children.name: Prototype
How far does Java OSGi take us?
Far enough for a prototype.
Can we develop a service-oriented system?
Yes. OSGi services were factored into bundles by functionality.
Bundles define interdependencies at the java package level which can be hard to manage over time.
Service lifecycles needs to be tracked by implementing OSGi interfaces.
Can we mix in other languages?
Yes. Use languages implemented on the JVM (e.g. Jython, JRuby, Scala, Groovy, etc.).
Can we improve development productivity using OSGi?
Yes. Individual OSGi bundles can be compiled and deployed into a running OSGi container.
Improvement over compile and restart, but we can do better.
Can we do a RESTful API in Jython?
Yes. CherryPy was deployed as an OSGi bundle.
Can we adopt git everywhere?
Yes
Nginx or Apache?
Nginx
Could Apache Buildr be a better build tool than Ant or Maven for a Java build tool?
Yes. Simple and declarative syntax with the full capabilities of Ruby.
No XML and less plugin headaches.
Can we support Jython and CPython from the same codebase?
Yes
Can we interact with deployed code?
Yes
Throw out all legacy code?
No...
... isolate legacy code to be replaced later!
How far does the GitHub issue tracker take us?
Far enough for early stage development
Can we use Groovy with OSGi to make Java less painful?
Yes. Groovy's closures and DSL capabilities are a nice fit in a Java UI.
Can we use Scala with OSGi to make Java less painful?
Yes, but we...
do not have time to become experienced with Scala
have experience building algorithms in Java
